channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, ISIS Leader Known for His Brutality, Is Dead at 48
item.description: President Trump announced the death of al-Baghdadi, who transformed the Islamic State into a global terrorist network that conquered territory the size of Britain and directed horrific attacks in the West.
item.dc:creator: Rukmini Callimachi and Falih Hassan
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Most of the world learned of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in July 2014, when he mounted the pulpit of a mosque in Iraq to declare himself the head of a growing terrorist organization.

item.title: ISIS Leader al-Baghdadi Is Dead, Trump Says
item.description: President Trump said in a nationally televised address that American forces targeted Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the head of the Islamic State, in an operation in Syria this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: In announcing the raid, President Trump put himself in the center of the action, describing himself as personally hunting Mr. al-Baghdadi since the early days of his administration.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Brawl With Protesters Outside Luxury Hotel
item.description: Demonstrators were expressing support for South Asians in the city, a week after the police sprayed stinging dye at a mosque.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Alexandra Stevenson and Katherine Li
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers clashed with protesters in Tsim Sha Tsui on Sunday.

item.title: ‘No Regrets’: Hong Kong’s Protesters Test China’s Limits
item.description: Hard-line demonstrators and the embattled authorities are locked in an impasse.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs, Tiffany May and Lam Yik Fei

item.title: Catholic Bishops Back Ordination of Married Men as Priests in Amazon Region, a Milestone
item.description: It was the first time a summit of bishops convened by a pope has endorsed such a historic change to the tradition of a celibate priesthood. The final decision will be up to the pope.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

item.title: Panic in Pakistani City After 900 Children Test Positive for H.I.V.
item.description: Health workers say the reuse of syringes drove the outbreak in the city of Ratodero.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: Four of Imtiaz Jalbani’s six children contracted H.I.V. His two youngest, 14-month-old Rida and 3-year-old Sameena, have died.

item.title: ‘Hitler or Höcke?’ Germany’s Far-Right Party Radicalizes
item.description: In elections on Sunday, the AfD is set to make another strong showing in eastern Germany. Its local leader, Björn Höcke, is considered an extremist by the intelligence service.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Björn Höcke of the far-right party Alternative for Germany at an election rally in Königs Wusterhausen, in eastern Germany in August.

item.title: In Afghanistan’s War and Peace, WhatsApp Delivers the Message
item.description: WhatsApp has proliferated in the highest echelons of the Afghan government — as well as among the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Mujib Mashal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Both Afghan soldiers and Taliban fighters regularly use WhatsApp to communicate on and off the battlefield.

item.title: In Hungary, Viktor Orban Showers Money on Stadiums, Less So on Hospitals
item.description: The Hungarian prime minister has created what critics call a semi-autocracy at the heart of democratic Europe. But he has largely ignored his country’s health care system.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The deterioration of hospitals while public money backs state-of-the-art soccer stadiums reflects the priorities of Prime Minister Viktor Orban.

item.title: U.K. Truck Driver Charged With Manslaughter in Deaths of 39
item.description: Maurice Robinson, 25, has been held for questioning since the grisly discovery of the bodies in a truck in Essex, England.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph and Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: Catholics in Nghe An Province, Vietnam, praying Saturday for the 39 people found dead early Wednesday in the back of a truck in Britain. Their nationalities were still being determined, but some of them may have been Vietnamese.

item.title: Pocketbook Woes Drive an Unlikely Comeback in Argentine Presidential Race
item.description: President Mauricio Macri rose to office with a promise that free markets would wrest Argentina from its boom-and-bust cycle. But with the country in recession, voters may now turn to an archrival.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Peter Bauza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rallies for President Mauricio Macri show that he still enjoys plenty of support, but whether he can broaden his base is another question.

item.title: Even Eagles Have Data Roaming Limits, Researchers Find
item.description: When one bird being tracked by Russian scientists flew to Iran, its transmitter sent a flood of text messages that ate up the tracking budget.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Igor Karyakin, Russian Raptor Research and Conservation Network
item.media:description: Russian scientists are currently tracking 13 steppe eagles. The birds breed in Russia and Kazakhstan, but fly to South Asia for the winter.

item.title: 67 Killed in Ethiopia Unrest, but Nobel-Winning Prime Minister Is Quiet
item.description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, this year’s winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, was in Russia when the protests broke out and has yet to publicly comment on the violence.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition leader Jawar Mohammed demonstrating on Thursday in Addis Ababa.

item.title: A Brexit Logjam, in Three Dimensions
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, the Labour Party and the European Union are all waiting for the other to make the next move. Meanwhile, Britons seethe.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson visiting a school in Milton Keynes, Britain, on Friday.

item.title: Transcript of Trump’s Remarks on the Death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi
item.description: “He died like a dog. He died like a coward. The world is now a much safer place,” the president said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: In announcing the raid, President Trump put himself in the center of the action, describing himself as personally hunting Mr. al-Baghdadi since the early days of his administration.

item.title: Special Operations Raid Said to Kill Senior Terrorist Leader in Syria
item.description: The identity of the target was not confirmed, but President Trump was scheduled to make a statement on Sunday morning.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Maggie Haberman and Rukmini Callimachi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: In announcing the raid, President Trump put himself in the center of the action, describing himself as personally hunting Mr. al-Baghdadi since the early days of his administration.

item.title: Iraqi Protesters Flood Baghdad Square Despite Violent Crackdown
item.description: A day after dozens were killed in antigovernment protests, the security forces shut off power in a central Baghdad square and launched barrages of tear gas and sound bombs.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters filled Tahrir Square in Baghdad on Saturday, the second day of renewed protests in Iraq.

item.title: Maria Butina, Deported to Moscow, Is Defiant: ‘Russians Don’t Give Up’
item.description: Ms. Butina, who befriended prominent Republicans during the 2016 election, served time in a Florida prison as an unregistered foreign agent.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

item.title: The Impeachment Inquiry This Week in 6 Developments
item.description: Details of a quid pro quo. Enter the “Deep State.” Steve Bannon is back. Revenge of the Republicans. And more.
item.dc:creator: Kaly Soto
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Morales Averts Runoff in Bolivia, Officials Say, but Anger and Doubt Remain
item.description: The election board’s finding incensed the opposition and raised international skepticism about a race dogged by allegations of fraud.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: President Evo Morales in La Paz on Thursday.

item.title: In Canada’s North, Art Emerges In the Face of Difficulty
item.description: Catherine Porter discusses the time she spent reporting in Cape Dorset, a place that struggles despite producing more artists per capita than big cities.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cape Dorset on the frozen edge of the Arctic Ocean.

item.title: Russian Conscript Kills 8 Soldiers in Shooting in Siberia
item.description: Officials identified the suspect as a private serving in a remote area along Russia's border with China, and blamed a “nervous breakdown.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Ramil Shamsutdinov, a Russian soldier, was accused of killing eight fellow servicemen on Friday.

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.description: De Niro and Pacino. Alyssa Milano. Flea. Taste-testing plant-based burgers. The sunless world of immigrants in Queens. And more.
item.dc:creator: Kaly Soto

item.title: U.S. to Deploy Hundreds of Troops to Guard Oil Fields in Syria, Pentagon Officials Say
item.description: Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper said the American strategy remains unchanged, although President Trump has said American forces are withdrawing,
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Syrian Democratic Forces at a check point near Omar oil field base, in eastern Syria, in February.

item.title: In One Afghan District, the Same Promises of Victory, 32 Years Apart
item.description: A Times reporter visits Baghlan Province, where, three decades ago, a Russian journalist documented the same assurances of peace offered to local residents by foreign commanders.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Indonesian Report on Lion Air Crash Finds Numerous Problems
item.description: Design flaws in the Boeing 737 Max led to the disaster last year, but an investigator said that without other factors “the crash would not have happened.”
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: Indonesian Navy personnel recovering wreckage from Lion Air Flight 610 last November.

item.title: A Bigger Role for Women in the Catholic Church? 185 Men Will Decide
item.description: Discussions at the Synod of Bishops for the Amazon have acknowledged that women must get recognition of some sort. But few expect real change.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo

item.title: Mystery of 39 Bodies in Truck Leads to More Arrests in U.K.
item.description: As officials tried to piece together clues from Belgium, Britain, Bulgaria, China and Ireland, a Vietnamese woman’s relatives said they feared she might be among the dead.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: The truck in which the 39 bodies were discovered in Grays, east of London, was driven to a secure location for further investigation on Wednesday.

item.title: China’s Response to Pence Speech: ‘Sheer Arrogance’
item.description: In a lengthy denunciation of the vice president, an official said he was trying to distract from American failings by criticizing Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence had criticized American companies for making compromises with China that conflict with Western values.

item.title: In a Quiet Corner, an Old Afghan Poet Polishes ‘the Heart’s Mirror’
item.description: For more than 50 years, Haidari Wujodi’s desk in a Kabul library has been a stop for those seeking escape from the violence outside.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Haidari Wujodi’s library desk is a place of pilgrimage for musicians, poets and students, among others.

item.title: California, Tulsi Gabbard, Betsy DeVos: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: ‘All of Them Are Thieves’: Iraqis Defy Security Forces to Protest Corruption
item.description: Demonstrations resumed despite government offers of new jobs, more money for housing and a crackdown on corruption. At least 30 people were reported killed.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: Protesters in Baghdad climbed barriers leading to the Green Zone on Friday.

item.title: Botswana Election Won by President, Despite Rift with Predecessor
item.description: President Mokgweetsi Masisi will serve another term after taking controversial steps to lift a ban on elephant hunting and usher in the decriminalization of homosexuality.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Mokgweetsi Masisi of Botswana voting at his home village of Moshupa on Wednesday. The party with the most seats chooses the president.

item.title: In Mexico City, a Blossoming of All Things Japanese
item.description: Japanese-inspired businesses are sprouting up — from fashion labels and boutiques to a new hotel — along with new Japanese-influenced places to eat and drink.
item.dc:creator: Brooke Porter Katz
item.media:credit: Adrian Wilson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Little Tokyo is buzzier than ever in Mexico City.

item.title: Scientists Were Hunting for the Next Ebola. Now the U.S. Has Cut Off Their Funding.
item.description: Predict, a government research program, sought to identify animal viruses that might infect humans and to head off new pandemics.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: A man prepares chickens for sale at the a market in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Poultry may carry influenza viruses that are transmitted to humans.

item.title: Pentagon, With an Eye on China, Pushes for Help From American Tech
item.description: Talks over how U.S. companies can ensure future supplies of advanced computer chips have taken on more urgency.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 7 Combat Deployments in 6 Years, Then a Bullet Nearly Killed Him
item.description: Jeffery Dawson wasn’t supposed to be on the mission that nearly killed him, but the Army’s failure to recruit enough bomb-disposal technicians for his unit meant there was no one else to go.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Sgt. First Class Jeffery M. Dawson received the Distinguished Service Cross, the nation’s second-highest medal for valor, in 2015.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Brexit, Ukraine, Earthquakes: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Chinese Lease of Entire Island Is Deemed Illegal in Solomons
item.description: The sweeping deal, signed by the head of a provincial government and executives from a Beijing-based conglomerate, had shocked residents.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Tulagi was a headquarters for world powers both before and during World War II and today has around 2,000 residents.

item.title: Does Australia Have to Bring Its Women and Children Home From Syria’s Camps?
item.description: How did the women and children end up in the camps? Is it true they were all forced or tricked? We answer your questions about the unfolding situation.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women and children in the foreigners section at Al Hol detention camp in Syria in March.

item.title: Bolivian Court Orders Partial Presidential Revote
item.description: The court’s decision means yet another delay for Bolivians waiting to hear who won their country’s election last Sunday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters in La Paz demanding a second-round presidential election on Thursday.

item.title: John Mbiti, 87, Dies; Punctured Myths About African Religions
item.description: A theologian and an Anglican priest, he argued that traditional African religions deserved the same respect as Christianity, Islam, Judaism and Buddhism.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: The theologian John Mbiti in 1970. He disputed characterizations of African religions as anti-Christian at best, practiced by savages at worst — labels that were once used to justify imperialism and slavery.

item.title: A Climbing Ban at Uluru Ends a Chapter. But There’s More to This Australian Story.
item.description: While the ban on ascending the iconic rock is a once-unthinkable victory for an Aboriginal people, they still face material hardship and a measure of resistance.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay and Matthew Abbott

item.title: Brexit, China, Bangladesh: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Breaking the Brexit deadlock.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: Pence Says U.S. Companies Leave ‘Conscience at the Door’ Over China
item.description: In a speech on the United States’ China policy, the vice president said companies should adhere to American values. He criticized Nike and the N.B.A.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: “By exploiting corporate greed, Beijing is attempting to influence American public opinion,” Vice President Mike Pence said on Thursday.

item.title: Earthquakes Are Jolting the Netherlands. Gas Drilling Is to Blame.
item.description: Tremors from extraction are blighting 350 square miles. Thousands of homeowners claim damage, and production will end in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Julia Gunther for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ceiling of the 15th-century Hippolytus Church in Middelstum in the Netherlands has been damaged by tremors linked to the extraction of natural gas in the area.

item.title: Russian Circus Bear Mauls Its Handler, Terrifying Crowd Just Yards Away
item.description: The circus manager said neither the trainer nor the bear were seriously injured, and blamed spectators for provoking the animal with flashes from cellphone cameras.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

item.title: Boris Johnson Calls for December Election in Push to Break Brexit Deadlock
item.description: Britain’s prime minister challenged lawmakers to approve a general election, but the opposition Labour Party reacted coolly to the idea.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler

item.title: Turkish and Kurdish Forces Said to Clash in Syria
item.description: Military forces maneuvered for position after an American withdrawal, apparently violating a United States-brokered cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Turkish soldier securing a road before an army tank started moving toward the Syrian border. Russia and Turkey held talks on how to divide control of Syria, devastated by eight years of civil war.

item.title: China Holds #MeToo Activist Who Wrote About Hong Kong Protests
item.description: She spoke critically of China’s restrictions on free speech. Now the authorities are accusing her of “provoking trouble.”
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Huang Xueqin, an activist, was detained by the police in the southern city of Guangzhou.

item.title: American Held in Russia on Spying Charge Must Stay in Prison
item.description: Paul H. Whelan, a Marine veteran arrested last December, said in court that a prison guard had assaulted him. He said he had been framed and that Russia held him hostage to be exchanged.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Paul N. Whelan, center, arrested in Russia in December 2018, is escorted to a hearing in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: In India, Release of Hate Crime Data Depends on Who the Haters Are
item.description: Officials chose to disclose figures about attacks committed by left-wing extremists but not religious-based crimes or violence against journalists.
item.dc:creator: Kai Schultz, Suhasini Raj, Jeffrey Gettleman and Hari Kumar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sardar Singh Jatav, center, a Dalit who was attacked by upper-caste Hindus last year.

item.title: What We Know About the U.K. Truck Deaths
item.description: The police say that the victims are believed to be from China, and that investigators have found out how the truck and container entered Britain, but there are still far more questions than answers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wolgelenter
item.media:description: The truck in which the 39 bodies were discovered in Grays, east of London, was driven to a secure location for further investigation on Wednesday.

item.title: Bangladesh Sentences 16 to Death for Young Woman’s Burning
item.description: After Nusrat Jahan Rafi accused a teacher of touching her, she was murdered in a case that shook the country.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Julfikar Ali Manik
item.media:description: Outside the courtroom in Feni, Bangladesh, on Thursday. Prosecutors said that Siraj Ud Doula, second from right, had ordered the killing from jail.

item.title: In Northern Ireland, Brexit Deal Is Seen as ‘Betrayal’
item.description: Enraged by the deal’s plan to effectively put a border in the Irish Sea, hundreds of members of loyalist paramilitary groups met this week to discuss how to respond.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural to the Ulster Volunteer Force, a unionist paramilitary group, in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

item.title: In China, FIFA’s Focus Is Soccer, Not Human Rights
item.description: After faulting the United States and Canada last year, FIFA is more muted as it brings a new tournament to China.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Tariq Panja
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: FIFA President Gianni Infantino announced that an expanded club world championship would be held in China in 2021.

item.title: As Putin Era Begins to Wane, Russia Unleashes a Sweeping Crackdown
item.description: A wave of arrests against journalists, opposition activists, doctors and religious believers raises a question: Is this a police state in the making or just a highly dysfunctional one?
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ksenia Ivanova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Svetlana Prokopyeva, a freelance journalist in Pskov, Russia, is facing up to seven years in jail after being accused of “publicly inciting terrorism” with her commentary.

item.title: 39 Bodies Found in Truck Are Likely Chinese, U.K. Police Say
item.description: The driver, identified as Morris Robinson, 25, remained under arrest on suspicion of murder. Investigators were also at work in Belgium and Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: The truck in which the 39 bodies were discovered in Grays, east of London, was driven to a secure location for further investigation on Wednesday.

item.title: A Hard-Fighting Indonesian Lawyer’s Death Has Colleagues Asking Questions
item.description: The police say Golfrid Siregar crashed his motorcycle. Environmentalists and human rights advocates doubt it.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock

item.title: Facebook, California, World Series: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: The Cost of Trump’s Aid Freeze in the Trenches of Ukraine’s War
item.description: As President Trump froze military aid to Ukraine and urged it to investigate his rivals, the country was struggling in a bare-bones fight against Russian-backed separatists.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers digging fresh trenches and bunkers after recently withdrawing about 500 yards from their previous position in Stanytsia Luhanska.

item.title: A French Wine From China? This $300 Bottle Is the Real Thing
item.description: A Rothschild estate in Shandong Province has released its first vintage. It was 10 years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Domaine de Long Dai, the Chinese wine estate that the owners of Château Lafite Rothschild in France decided to establish a decade ago.
